segments.text: Yeah, you were standing next to MacArthur at a parade at West Point.
Yeah, shoulder to shoulder, and he's no taller than I am.
He's not as tall.
He's probably about the same.
I'm going by his shoulder.
And I was really surprised because he, of course, he's old, was then, but he's dead now.
And one, as you get old, kind of, you know, you just don't look as robust and kind of stoop maybe to the shoulders, but...
I always thought, because all of his pictures, he controlled that.
You could do that in World War II, that he would never take a picture next to someone that he was considerable shorter than.
And he'd always have the pictures taken at a lower angle.
But he was a brilliant, particular writer.
but not quite the total individual either.
So in your opinion, Marshall would be the finest later in the war.
He even agreed to or wanted, you know, Churchill wanted him to take Eisenhower's job or to be that meaningful.
But Marshall, of course Roosevelt wanted to keep him in Washington, but didn't discourage him, but Marshall just felt that
He could do more for the effort here.
He had already started, you know, and got all this going support.
But Marshall, all through the years, not only that, not only was he a leader, but he trained and developed people.
If you look at some of these others, by that I mean he groomed them.
And he had a knack of
He selected all of our generals in World War II.
Of course, he had recommendations of others.
But he knew all of them.
But mainly because of being such a statesman, Akers sort of proves to me that he had qualities and a depth of character and personality that you don't find in very many people.
He probably would have made a great president, for example.
Certainly much better than Eisenhower.
Oh, Eisenhower wasn't a bad one, but I don't think history would judge him as being, I think he's probably a mediocre one, which most of them are.
For sure.
It isn't half the truth.
Well, let's finish up on the German campaign.
Once you got into Germany and once you crossed the Rhine, got into Germany, how did you get along with the German civilians?
They were our enemies.
Yeah, and we weren't permitted to fraternize.
And I left on VE Day, so I hardly, I got along because they cooperated very well.
And the Burgermeister had the town, if you told that Burgermeister that
to get this street cleared here.
You know, they had debris and so forth.
Man, he'd have women and children out there doing it.
He didn't say, oh, but there's no men.
I just got women and children.
Did you liberate any of the concentration camps?
Unfortunately, yes.
Which ones?
I didn't think there was any.
Not one of the big ones, but this is a journey.
Just a minute, I think I've got my own world.
I have quite a few females that are...
The name is Landsberg, L-A-N-D-S-B-E-R-G. Yeah.
That's not the album I'm looking for, but that's the information I'm looking for.
And...
And those females there.
Tell me about, yeah, tell me, what was it like going into Landsberg?
Well, it's very similar to all these other pictures you've seen of the larger ones with ovens for burning.
But they had what I would call chicken cooks.
They're low where a person can't stand and kneel.
Mm-hmm.
And they would put those people in there, and they would die.
You'd think they're all dead, but you look real close, and you could barely see pulsation, you know, about like this in the stomach.
Nothing but skin and bones.
And they had some women, like the ones that you see there, that the only thing I can figure that they fed them and maintained them for sex purposes, because they had a lot of women with them.
perfectly normal looking.
And they were inside enclosure, but they had freedom.
But they had cars like you saw that stacked with bodies, and the stench was just terrible.
They had some who were still skin and bones that walked around but didn't know where they were, couldn't talk.
What did you do for these people?
There wasn't much we could do.
The division, I think, got the German stuff, particularly in the villages around.
They brought in a whole fleet of doctors and specialists.
But there isn't much you can do for those that are already in the past.
It's just a hell of a humane thing to get them out of their misery.
But they tried to sort through them just like you would to find out those that are salvageable, those that need immediate medical attention.
But except for those women, none of them were in good condition.
You didn't see any health of male prisoners.
It's just as if they were, which is better to go ahead and use the oven and get rid of them than to torture these people.
Well, sure.
Starve them to death.
And the Germans claimed they knew nothing about it, but the stink, you could smell it for miles.
They must have known something like that.
Because they'd say, what is that bad smell?
Plus, the Germans must have, the men that guarded the barracks, or guarded Landsberg, must have gone into town sometime.
But the civilians...
They just said that they didn't know anything about it.
Yeah, I have to admit, this was a way.
You could see Landsberg from where this camp was, but it wasn't right in the outskirts.
It was a distance, but I don't see any keeping smelling that.
Then we had trouble after, once again, those poor individuals
that could walk.
Of course, they all wanted to leave.
Go wandering out to the community, and you couldn't have that.
Those you had to try to get to a hospital.
So you had to keep almost them under guard, which that was even pitiful.
After finally getting freedom, still keep them under guard.
Just for reference, we should
cite this book, The Pictorial History of the 36th Texas Infantry Division.
Who wrote this?
Published in Austin, Texas.
Edited by Staff Sergeant Richard A. Huff, H-U-F-F. Yeah, that was done as an official, you know, it wasn't any group work, though.
That was an active duty type of thing.
And we should have this in a footnote.
That's a nice book.
Now, you continued on.
And at this time, you caught, not you, but you caught Gehring, Herman Gehring.
Tell me about that.
He has pictures in the back.
Right there.
Well, I wasn't there when that happened.
Oh, you weren't?
And von Rundstedt surrendered.
You weren't there either?
No.
Okay.
I left.
This all happened after VE Day.
Right, when they were trying to get into it.
And I left.
Well, I was in England, London on VE Day, so I left a day or two before that.
Okay.
But that was a big flap about this.
Did you get into Austria?
Did you get into Austria?
Into Brooklyn.
Mm-hmm.
Yeah, into Brooklyn.
Mm-hmm.
In fact, we ended the war just...
They were going not too far from where we left Italy to come back around.
They had to go all through France.
On the menu the day that they had him, they had fried chicken.
And they fed Goring the same meal that everybody else had.
But the press really jumped on about entertaining this filthy Nazi.
And of course, they were treating him
as a fellow officer.
He had no purpose or reason to treat him as a convicted Nazi like a lay owner in a war trial.
Of course, they never got him jailed, but he committed suicide.
He was a prisoner.
And so you got into Austria.
And at this time, did you ever have any opportunity to meet any of the Russians?
No.
You never met any Russians at all.
Was there any difference between how you were treated by the German people and how you were treated by the Austrians?
I really wasn't in Austria long enough.
When you left on VE Day, were you eager to go home or to the Pacific, or what were your thoughts?
Well, I was eager to go home.
But I knew that I was going to the school to Command General Staff College to prepare for really the invasion of Japan.
In fact, our course there used the, it was classified, although it wasn't identified what it was, because it didn't use the Japanese home island by name.
But it was really taking General MacArthur's plan
for the ground invasion of the home of Japan.
And after we had finished, then we were prepared to go join General MacArthur's staff or other staff.
What did you think of the command in General Staff College?
Oh, it was a six-month course in 1945?
No, this too was about three months.
But it was still a short war course.
Yeah.
Okay, what did you think about that college?
I thought it was very good because I'd had all of the basic training, and I had all of the World War II experience from a second lieutenant to a...
I was a regimental executive officer at the end of the war, a lieutenant colonel, regimental executive officer.
And I wanted to, of course, get the experience of the command and stuff.
Sure.
Had you made up your mind when you heard on VJ Day that the war was over, were you convinced that you wanted to continue in the service and complete the career?
Yeah.
Did you ever think of any other alternative?
Maybe after five years, maybe you wanted to go back to dairy husbandry or anything like that?
Yeah, well, as I said earlier,
If I hadn't gotten a regular commission, see, because that would have meant, after all of this experience, I'm still a young man.
As I recall, I was only 28 years old, seeing a lieutenant colonel.
If I wasn't qualified for a regular army commission, well, I certainly didn't think I was qualified to stay on in the reserve also.
It was time to get.
So I planned, if I didn't get a regular commission, I'd go back to A&M and probably
a couple better there.
And during this time, of course, this is rapid demobilization.
America's army just shrinks in 12,
military shrinks in 12 million to a million and a half in just a year and a half, and a number of officers are losing ground as far as rank because it was a temporary promotion.
Did you go from a lieutenant colonel down a grade?
We were very fortunate because Sweet Larson, who later on became a
Lieutenant General commanded the Army out to Presidio, California.
He was the aid to the Chief of Staff.
And Eisenhower had indicated that for morale purposes, we should move from temporary rank back to permanent rank.
Well, Swede Larson was the aid to the
I forgot who the chief of staff was.
In fact, some had already been moved from a colonel to a lieutenant colonel.
They thought at the time that you'd lose your colonel, but you would become a senior lieutenant colonel.
But they found out by law, after they'd already reduced that colonel, he couldn't.
He had to go way back to what he was as a lieutenant colonel.
And so that meant that
He had attained rank, most of them battlefield promotions, like mine.
He would be working for someone who never got to be colonel, who maybe hadn't even fought in World War II.
He would be junior to him.
Well, old Swede Larson convinced his boss that this is going to have a tremendous effect on the Army, because it's going to affect more people
On the upper end, those whose morale is enhanced or boosted because of the reduction of the junior, although I can see their point.
They say, my gosh, this guy here went, in my case, from a second lieutenant to a lieutenant colonel, and quite a senior lieutenant colonel by that time, in about two and a half years.
Here, I've been in the Army, they say, 20 years, 22, maybe even longer.
And I'm a lieutenant colonel.
Why should I be serving under this young guy the rest of my career?
It's not my fault, says he, that I was kept at Leavenworth or somewhere like Major Orr I told you about when he was at A&M.
He was the prison officer at Leavenworth because he was over age for combat.
Because combat has to be, as a young, I could never pull it as a battalion commander if I hadn't been young, up in those holes.
So you can see, in fact, the first time I saw him, while I was a student at the Command and Staff College, I ran across, he's a lieutenant colonel then.
And he looked at me and he said, Andrew,
You're a lieutenant colonel.
And he looked at his own shoulder.
And I'm a lieutenant.
You were a cadet student in my class.
Here you rank the same rank as I am.
But fortunately, it didn't get down to me.
A lot of colonels were reduced to lieutenant colonels.
But they stopped after they found out
was going to have on those, because those were, some of them were as young as I was, but they ended up awarding the colonels.
I almost was the colonels.
I was a regimental executive.
I was going to be promoted pretty soon to regimental commander.
And also had a lot of other morale to be young.
At Fort Benning, I was an instructor there.
Right, and that's where you went right after September 1945 and stayed there until 1948 at Fort Benning.
And you see, I was a 28-year-old lieutenant colonel, and I rated because of rank, a big set of quarters.
On each side of me were officers.
When I was a lieutenant colonel, who
much older in most service, you know.
So some of them felt that some of us got promoted too fast, too soon.
Well, once again, the only reason we got promoted fast, so soon, so quickly, was because of the war.
The survival of the fittest, not the fittest, the luckiest.
Yeah, that was a very interesting assignment because
I was in the training management part.
And that was part of the general section.
And what exactly is that?
Well, in the general section, which I remember, we had leadership, map reading.
Training management was methods of instruction, training to be an instructor.
We ran the course on all new instructors had to take just about a week's course.
Then we were graduating about one OCS class a day.
It was really this peak.
Of course, it cut back at the BJ day.
But we still had all of these in the pipeline.
And so most of our load was also candidate school.
And as soon as BJ day, did you immediately cut down?
Well, it gradually cut down to one every other day, and then finally one a week, and then cut back on it.
But besides the methods of instruction, or how to be an instructor and the technique of instruction, the management of
Training in as an S3, for example, how do you make out a training schedule?
How you should schedule certain subjects, those which involve physical activity after lunch, for example.
And although they ought to say now you shouldn't do that, you should have something else.
But you go to sleep after lunch, particularly young guys that have been working hard, that type of thing.
Training aids.
the types, how do you make them and how you use them, techniques and so on.
That sounds more educational than military.

Yeah, it was a, it was a, but very important on techniques on the stage and the, you even got people who don't even, just don't think they'll, they'll believe the troops out in the sun or face in the sun.
So the instructor doesn't have to look in the sun.
Here, those poor devils got to sit there and stand.
At least you can see them where both of them have some sun and no sun.
It was during this time that you attended glider school.
Why?
Well, because we were teaching not in ours, but out in yours.
There they taught us.
how to load and lash gliders.
You know, we were still using them then.
Sure, absolutely.
We used them in France.
We would even use dual tow with the C-47.
And so, since we were involved with that, we had their department involved with us.
We taught classes down there.
I just wanted to broaden myself and know about it.
Plus, you got glider badges.
That's just another...
So it's partially ambitious, part ego, part adventure, I guess.
During this time, right when you were about to leave in 1948, President Truman
had an executive order, pronounced an executive order, in which he integrated the armed services and started to have all the units integrated in the army.
Do you remember that?
What was your opinion of that?
Well, it was
It was inefficient, really, to have all black units.
Not only was it inefficient for the military structure, but it contributed to a disciplinary problem.
And it tended to

highlight because you did have this one with all those blacks together and so forth that the blacks were troublemakers because all you had to have one or two to get into trouble and of course they said what's that damn black unit you know again they can't trust them so i thought that was a good step now there's one thing that i don't think
that the military should be used for, and that's to solve social problems in our society.
Now, Truman made the military guinea pigs on this, see?
And it worked out fairly well.
We still had colored units and black units in the Korea War.
They did better, for example.
with white officers than they did with black officers.
Now, that doesn't mean that the black officer is not as good as the white officer.
It just means that the blacks seem to respond better to white officers because they're one of us, and I'm a second-class citizen.
In other words, our prestigious stature will be enhanced by having white officers.
That was their feeling.
I'm told.
I never served with one, but I spent some time in Korea.
And as a staff visit or an observer, when I went to check on their cadets who were in Korea and survived at that time.
And since then, it's just been proven.
We've got so many outstanding black officers, for example,
particularly the Air Force.
I can't call his name now, but he's really a top fighter pilot and leader.
But we're facing the same thing now with using females in the armed forces.
We'll get to that later.
As far as the blacks are concerned, did you ever, when you were in Europe in the campaign in Europe, did you ever work with or alongside any totally black units?
No.
Because most of them were service units, water master, transportation.
And they were back in the supply areas.
And I don't remember ever seeing the black up in the area in the forward position.
Well, I've seen the truck drivers, because we used a long haul, had a name for it.
Red Ball Express went all across France and then Germany.
A lot of those drivers were black.
In fact, many of them were, some of them.
But no, I never did have any.
Of course, I was raised with black.
Some of my friends, good friends in Caldwell were black.
Of course, they didn't go to school with us.
We had black schools.
But that was so stupid and inefficient to run two facilities.
But it's turned out it does.
It's worked to the disadvantage to the black, because the black teachers have great difficulty here in Austin, same way, to compete with white teachers and coaches, you know, that sort of thing.
And if they've been discriminated against, it's just that at least they appear not to be as well qualified.
So in Cowell, when they integrated the school, they lost a bandmaster.
They lost a coach.
They lost some teaching and administrative people who were functioning on that because you just didn't need them, which makes it so inefficient, of course, to operate two systems.
You've got to have management people.
Were you happy when you got the assignment to West Point?
Oh, yeah.
Yeah.
Because I wanted to be a cadet.
didn't make it, so I figured this would be the second best thing.
Of course, the cadets said, this is the best thing.
They said, did you get here?
You're up here for four years.
Of course, it was a assignment.
It was three years.
I've extended a year.
They said, here you are.
You're going through the same thing we are, and you're going through as a lieutenant colonel, and we have to go through as a cadet.
Now, there's one thing that I have often heard about the West Point.
versus the Aggie officers, and that is that some people have charged that there is a sort of West Point protective agency or whatever.
And I was wondering, is that what you found in your military group?
Just the opposite.
Just the opposite.
They had to lean over backwards.
Well, of course, I admit that you have to...
You can't goof off.
I mean, if you're a problem guy, of course, West Point has nothing to do with that.
I mean, everybody certainly is.
Thank you.
Oh, yes, I always heard that.
Most of that is a sour grapes type of thing.
They call them the ring knockers.
Whenever they get together, the first thing they do, and that's to let everybody know I'm a West Pointer, you know, for the rest of them.
So all of the ring knockers can excuse themselves and go in there.
plot how they're going to run the army and run the military.
No.
Just the opposite.
Besides the luck I keep preaching about, I have been helped by West Point all through my career.
I mentioned about Denholm, for example, coming and replacing the battalion commander Jones that was captured.
He taught me so much, and I often thought that if I hadn't had the experience with him, if I'd had Jones to continue on.
Nothing I have means to say derogatory against National Guard officers.
I was one myself.
But some of those officers had never been trained.
Some of them, even up in New York, it was a social club.
They played polo, and it was just like a...
It's very difficult to get in.
It was a closed type of thing.
You had others who, in the community, they had been, for example, life insurance business.
So they weren't professionals.
They had solicited from all the people they were commanding, and they weren't about to offend them.
They didn't like to discipline anybody.
A professional officer, a regular army officer, if he's fair and if he has duty in our country, he'd go to look at everybody the same way.
And then on came in, and I'd had more experience than most of the National Guard officers, because I'd been in the Army, the regular Army unit, for a year.
Plus, I'd had a couple of summer camps, one summer camp before I went on Thomas tonight, two weeks.
But I hadn't been to the basic school of competing until as a National Guard officer.
So everything I'd learned, but I learned about morning report and all the other things.
a lot of management, such as supply, mess, how to inventory things.
So at least I had some knowledge, but I still had a lot to learn from Denholm.
Now, Denholm ended up a major general, but he was a real intellectual.
He wasn't a spit and polish guy.
In fact, he even wore his uniform kind of like most people would put their trousers and their boots and blouses.
Not Denholm.
He puts them in and crimps them.
I don't mean he didn't shine his brass and all that, but I just meant that he wasn't like Captain Moses I mentioned.
You could just take his picture and put it in a magazine and say, here's how a uniform should be worn.
What did you learn from Denholm?
The main thing I learned was standards.
If a soldier, for some reason or another, ran off and left his rifle or radio, well, the trucking officer said, well, this is combat.
The guy said, you know, people get killed, not dental.
He called in the guy and he says, where did you leave it?
Oh, what was the situation?
Oh, gosh, they were firing and that sort of thing.
He says, all right, you're going back and get it.
Well, I can't do that.
He said, Art, you need a court martial there.
Government equipment costs the taxpayers a lot of money.
And you have a responsibility to safeguard it.
If you could get out safely, you could have brought out your rifle or a radio.
In this case, I think it was a radio.
And so he sent him back and got it.
He didn't get hurt.
He came back with equipment.
And boy, the word spread all around him.
You better not leave it in the lake with that guy.
He'll send you back to get it.
Of course, he was doing that.
He was a real leader.
He knew it impressive.
Another thing, we had people who would pitch their tent, and because they'd be too lazy to use a tent peg and put it in, they would tie it to a tree.
And, of course, the wind blows a tree, and it strikes a tent, and any fool knows that.
With Denholm, he would have them lined up, and if they weren't lined up, we're talking about out of the line now, see?
But he knew that's
Standards must be established away from combat.
And he was, and he built that unit up morale.
See, this is after the Soleil-Colore deal, you know.
And they were feeling sorry for themselves, those who survived.
We had some who made it out across, and they lost their friends, you know.
Boy, this is really tough.
And he really bucked them up.
So he had standards.
And he set the example.
Yet he was fair and he would listen, but he expected you to do the same thing that he did.
And pretty soon you saw the unit.
They just stood up a little tall.
You saw that they were.
And this is what makes you feel good as a commander.
You'd be marching down the road, and there are other units there.
Those units look just like us before Denholm, and you'll hear the soldiers say,
He said, look at that area.
How do they get by with that?
You know, they're the only ones that have standards.
Now they're comparing it.
Before then, they didn't know it.
Well, everybody does that.
But see, once again, living above the level of the common mass.
So he worked with us, and they responded to people that respected him at first.
They thought he was a West Pointer.
You know, that's who he's bred.
Well, he's one of those.
But pretty soon, they...
recognized that Denholm was a leader.
He had standards.
He expected us.
What he was doing was for our own good.
The mess improved, because he supervised the mess.
He'd come around.
There's a battalion commander.
He goes, those messes.
And he knew what was on the daily menu.
He says, all right, let me see.
You've got potatoes in there.
And of course, they were dehydrated potatoes.
And he'd go take a look at it.
Of course, it cooked and ruined them by adding so much water.
You know, it's not even tomato soup.
It would be some kind of a problem.
And he found things, and he knew how.
He'd been to a cook's and baker's school.
And why he did it, it's like I went to glider school.
Not that he was ever going to be a cook or baker, but he would be a better judge, apparently.
And so he knew about it.
And he'd get the package out and say, you're just not preparing this properly.
And it isn't fair to the men.
I don't care about you, but they're the ones that have to eat it.
And I could go on and on.
And so the next time we went into combat, we did much better and carried this work as high.
We didn't lose any equipment.
We didn't leave anybody on the so-called battlefield.
I know that people have criticized the Marines because they'll go out and risk life
more life to save, try to save somebody that's needed.
But it's not the bodies in it count, it's just like the Aggie spirit, it's the spirit of the thing.
Knowing that if I'm out there, somebody's going to come and get me, or try their damnedest thing.
So it really helps the unit.
So then after we came out of the line again, we were surprised we were going training.
Oh, we're combat troops, you know, we don't train.
Oh, yes.
We would have village training, see.
So I was out training, and this was good.
It got their mind off of all their problems, you know, the family at home and the ones in law.
And they used to smoke and all the other things.
They used to take infantry coordination.
And we got to be village experts.
And you don't have as many cases, because everybody knows what they're doing.
And it's a team.
It's just like a Dallas Cowboys working out and working.
So that's what I say.
He was a real leader, and he was fair.
The next one was Paul D. Adams, who retired now as a general.
Was he a West Point?
Yeah.
So he was a regimental commander that replaced Martin, the one who was so unhappy about everything.
The one who met me at the train and so forth.
Paul D. Adams, same thing.
Now, I came to Paul D.M.
I'd never known him before, potentially.
And he was a regimental commander.
And I was in Denholm's battalion, see.
But I knew what was going on.
I got to be Denholm's S3.
In fact, I was his S3 at the Rapido River.
I wasn't the company commander there.
I give you an example of the fairness of where the Denholm and also Paul D. Adams contributed to my success, at least by promoting me.
We had some officers coming from the United States.
Paul D. Adams' classmate was coming over.
He was in the .
personnel pooh, particularly the senior officers when they placed them.
So he was looking for a position, he wanted a battalion, of course everybody did, was supposed to be a battalion commander.
And so he came to see Paul D. Adams, and Paul D. Adams said, well, yeah, I'll take you.
But he says, I want you to know that you're not coming as my classmate, you're coming to me as a
Lieutenant Colonel Replacement Battalion come in and you're not going to get any favors from me.
Oh yes, he understood that and so he went off.
So he came and he took the battalion.
Denholm went to another job and he took Denholm's battalion.
I guess Denholm became executive officer to Paul Neatom.
Yeah, that was it.
And he was a good guy.
We liked him.
Everything's going along fine.
He didn't quite have the standards, and he was kind of nervous a little bit.
But we were in Italy, outside of Rome, and I was up with the troops.
We were attacking.
And Paul D. Adams came up there.
He said, right now I can't call the battalion commander.
He says, where are the, I called the battalion commander.
And he said,
I said, well, I don't know.
He was here just a short time ago.
He may be back at the CP.
I don't know.
Why isn't he up here?
Here he's kind of chewing me out, you know, me and the exec.
In other words, he said, what the hell are you doing up here with the exec?
If anybody's back at the CP, it ought to be the exec.
And I said, well, he was just up here.
I thought I'd stay up here because there's some German tanks up ahead up here.
He says, all right.
So he left.
And
Later on, I don't know where he went, but later on, he had both of us as CP.
I guess I came back then.
Now, these are very mature individuals.
They're old.
He's a class of 30, 27, I believe.
And he called me in, I guess, as a witness, because it's a kind of poor leadership technique.
But he wanted me in there.
And he started chewing him out.
He gave him hell.
The commander, the battalion commander, he started chewing him out.
Yeah, and so he reacted by, of course, he was kind of relaxed, you know, with an attempt.
And he could see that old Paul Lee was really mad, so he came to the attention and put those heels together.
And he said, you came here as a battalion commander.
I told you that you wouldn't have any favoritism.
I'm not going to have a battalion commander that stays back in the CP.
while his unit is in attack, and certainly to have the exec up there instead of you.
At least you've got an exec that will go up there and see what's going on.
And he tried to tell him that I was just there and just left.
He was trying to tell him that he had a mission.
He had a legitimate reason.
No need for both of us to be up there.
And he interrupted me and said, I don't want to hear an excuse.
I know what I saw, and I don't want to ever see it again.
Now, you understand that.
I'm going to give you one more chance.
I'm going to relieve you and save you back.
Yes, sir.
And he saluted Boyle and marched him out.
So then we went into Southern France.
Meantime, Paul D. had moved me over to get me a 3rd Battalion, not the 2nd that I'd been in all the time.
And we've already talked about that.
Now, he's got the second battalion.
He happened to go in down by that airstrip where the Germans were.
And he led the attack as a lieutenant colonel out in front or with a two-lead company.
And the machine gun boy just got him from the shoulder all the way down like that.
He survived, no, but he's all shot up.
He can't walk in a wheelchair.
And there's no doubt in my mind that that chewing out by his classmate caused him to take undue chances that he shouldn't have taken and probably wouldn't have taken if he hadn't got this.
And so you don't find that at all.
You find just the opposite.
See, here I get praised and get promoted and given a battalion.
There's one West Pointer taken off after another West Pointer.
Yeah, and a classmate, see?
And I've seen many other, those experiences that I've had.
In other words, they're so interested, they're very interested in upholding the standards of West Point.
That's right.
The real ones.
And two, I got promoted to general officer in these other 70s or something.
Wow.
He's just amazed how many West Point graduates never make general losses.
Retires currently.
And the chief of staff we've had, non-West Point, that were selected by a West Point graduate.
So that doesn't give them it all.
I found just the option.
I said, I could go on and on.
So that's an unjust allegation.
Now, I'm sure that there are examples.
Sure, just like I was telling you about the Spirit of Agon and going and buying tires from Phoenix Data, there's some that would probably give somebody a break there.
But the real leaders that we have, they're not about to ever, they're bent over backwards the other way.
Now my boss at West Point, for example, was G, Ned G, West Point Accord.
There's only about three of us there that weren't driving.
Well, later on he got five.
And he has helped me through all my...
He's the one who made me the deputy head of the department or whatever the hell they call it, assistant.
He asked for me for another year, extension, see, four years, and gave me outstanding official reports, as Denholm did and all the others did.
And nearly every commander I've had
had been West Point graduate that I worked for.
Now what did you teach when you were at West Point?
Military psychology and leadership?
Leadership.
I went to Queens College for a while to take several courses in psychology.
Went there and we had a newly organized department.
We had it once before.
You know who organized it once before and then they finally phased it out?
General MacArthur.
Really?
And then they phased out.
Then they decided to do it.
See, they weren't teaching a course in psychology, basic psychology.
And they felt truly so that that was a void in the cadet's education.
Because from then on, it was all, of course, the other disciplines.
But there wasn't enough humanity.
So.
